answers.answer: Your blood pressure is far too high.  The blurry vision could be due to the high blood pressure and you will also no doubt be feeling dizzy when you stand up.  The high blood pressure will be causing the pressure in your head.Blurring vision can also be caused if the sugar levels in your body are too high.Make an appointment to see your doctor so that he can monitor your blood pressure.  He may do this over a short period of time before he decides whether you should be prescribed with blood pressure medication.   A blood test  (HBA1C) would also show whether your sugar levels are too high and whether you have diabetes.In the mean time, eat regularly (not junk food, cakes and sugar foods) and drink plenty of water so as not to get dehydrated.  Cut down on your intake of salt and salty foods - salt does increase blood pressure.Try and do some relaxation techniques to help you to relax.  Get help to hope with the stressors in your life and how to deal with them.  Stress is another factor that will spike up your blood pressure.Your doctor can help you with this, by prescribing something to help you to calm down in stressful situations and also refer you to a specialist counsellor to help you to how to tackle your problems.Going out for a walk in the fresh air is a good way to get calm.  This won't make the stressors go away, but will help you to calm down and see things from a different angle.Best wishes.

You are very lucky that you do not have hypertension.  It is probable that you did not over exceed on your salt intake.I too love lots of salt.Many years ago after having eaten a lot, and I mean a lot of home made gherkins that were pickled in brine (brine is salt and water) my blood pressure did go up drastically even though I am on medication for hypertension.The medical profession usually tells people with hypertension and fluid retention to cut down on the amount of salt.  There is also lots of evidence to prove that too much salt intake is not good for our bodies.I have copied and pasted the link below that explains in detail about salt and about studies that have been carried out with regard to health risks with regard to consuming too much salt.  The web page has no copy write logo and is not selling anything.Unfortunately, a lot of foods that we buy do have hidden salt and sugar and we cannot calculate correctly how much salt intake we do have in a day.  Our body does require some salt, but too much is not safe.http://www.actiononsalt.org.uk/salthealth/factsheets/pressure/index.html

Yeah I went well over the salt intake. I don't eat the refined table salt but rock salt. I recently just bought himalayan pink salt to try.  My blood pressure has only gone up with magnesium deficiency and hyperthyroidism.An interesting article is Real Salt is GOOD for you! Here is a few paragraphs..."And in this study[9] the risk for heart disease was 56% higher for the low-salt group than for the group who ate the most salt. Wow.And then we find a lot of studies linking salt restriction to increased LDL and triglycerides[10], insulin resistance[11], type 2 Diabetes[12] and sodium deficiency[13]. Cutting back on salt is not sounding so good now, really is it…Another interesting point to consider is that critically ill patients in hospital who cannot eat or drink are given a drip containing saline to keep them healthy. trying it out if it is any good.I use normal table salt and I know that contains something (may be powder of some sort) to keep it to flow freely.Well my diabetes (I now have Type 2, I was glucose intolerant for about 6 years), certainly wasn't anything to do with me having lack of salt :)Even when I was not allowed any salt when I was in the maternity ward 40 years ago and the food was so bland, I got my husband to sneak me in some salt.  (I had a lot of fluid retention at the time, can't remember if my blood pressure was raised or not at that time).With sick people it is slightly different.  When people are ill and do not eat and drink, they become dehydrated and have loss of electrolytes.  Salt is one of the minerals that our body does require, but not a lot.  And as you will probably be aware, dehydration can lead to death.You will probably know of the electrolyte replacement drinks that can be purchased when someone has severe sickness and diarrhea.  These have a balance of salt and sugar to replenish what has been lost.To be honest, a lot of people are probably consuming a lot more salt that is required for the body and what is recommend as being the safe level.  Unless you buy and make your own meals, ready made stuff, condiments like pickles, sauces contain salt, and then there are the crisps and snacks that contain salt.If we consume a lot of salt the body will compensate by making us feel very thirsty which will make us drink more and that no doubt will help to flush out the excess.  Have you ever experienced that?  Same goes for sugar if someone is glucose intolerant or has diabetes, if you consume too much sugar, you will feel very thirsty.I would be interest to know what you think of the pink Himalayan salt.  Why is it pink?  Is this it's natural colour or it is dyed to be pink as a novelty?Like the saying goes "Everything is good for you, in moderation".
